1.1 Latin American Feminist Origins (Pre-20th Century)

Most historical genealogies of Latin American feminism trace their
origins to the social movements beginning in the 1960s and 1970s
centered around women’s liberation. However, feminist ideas in
Latin America are much older than those which have been documented as
part of feminist political action. The origins of Latin American
feminist ideas can be found in reflections on conditions of otherness
that emerge as a result of colonialism and in critiques of norms that
render the category of man the entry point for humanity. By the 60s
and 70s, feminism in Latin America had a firmly rooted history
concerned with articulating difference and alterity from a
non-dominant perspective (Gargallo 2004: 80).

The existence of a genealogy of Latin American feminisms brings to the
fore the relationship between women and history. Getting to know the
past was a critical and necessary component of the feminist movements
of 60’s and 70’s. The past framed the existence of
historical examples of women’s struggles that served as
endorsements for the claims of feminist movements (Palacios
2007: 96). The failure of history to collect the life and action
of women required new perspectives, which came to include the search
for forgotten figures, attention to subjects like the body and female
sexuality, models of femininity, and attention to structural systems
of oppression as necessary points of departure for what would become
the genre of feminist of scholarship (Palacios 2007: 98). 

Notwithstanding, there are still lacunas in Latin American feminist
genealogy as the writings of non-white women from the 19th
and early 20th centuries (and earlier) are seldom found in
written form, given that many non-white women were illiterate, and
their stories were not textually documented. Their ideas and histories
were orally transmitted, and current local oral traditions account for
them (Gargallo 2010: 12a). Oral history projects enable contemporary
listeners to hear the voices of voiceless women and be witness to the
document of concerns that grow out of poverty and colonial obscurity
(Oliver 2018, 32). For instance, the colonial resistance of
Baraúnda, wife of Garifuna leader Satuyé, is legendary
for her people; her memory travels in songs sung by Garifuna women of
Honduras and Belize. Similarly, the story of Anacaona, Taino chief
(cacica) of Jaragua Hispañola, is one of colonial
resistance; prior to her execution she was offered clemency in return
for becoming a concubine for a Spaniard, and her refusal and
subsequent death solidified her legendary status which is immortalized
in songs from Haiti, Dominican Republic, and Puerto Rico. The stories
of Indigenous women of these times continue to be shared orally
through myth, songs, and proverbs, and contribute to the foundations
of Latin American feminist thought (Gargallo 2010: 14a).

One of the earliest documented writers in the Latin American feminist
tradition comes from the 17th century. Arguing in favor of
the educational and intellectual rights of women, Juana Inés
María del Carmen Martínez de Zaragoza Gaxiola de Asbaje
y Ramírez de Santillana Odonojú (1651–1695),
recognized by many as Juana Inés de la Cruz or Sor Juana of
Mexico, was a self-educated scholar of the Baroque period whose
writings have garnered quite a bit of philosophical attention as part
of the Latin American philosophical canon. She was well known during
her lifetime as evidenced by multiple publications of her work.
However, by the second half of the 18th century, her fame
diminished as attention to Baroque poetry declined. In 1951, her work
recovered attention with the publication of her complete works
(Gargallo 2009: 419). Subsequently, Juana Ines de la Cruz has
become an iconic Latin American feminist figure whose work exemplifies
the existence of lettered women intellectuals who resisted systems of
domination. For instance, Approaches to the Theory of Freedom in
Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz (2018) advances a philosophical
exploration on freedom in the corpus of Juana Ines’ and
methodologically situates her in the Mexican philosophical tradition
(Aspe Armella 2018).  Alternatively, in Feminist Perspectives
on Sor Juana Ines de La Cruz (ed. Stephanie Merrimm 1999) Juana
Ines is framed in terms of her feminist impact on literature and
culture in an anthology that bridges her from the past into the
present. 

Juana Inés de la Cruz was one among many feminist writers who
advocated for social and cultural changes, including the role of
women. Teresa Margarida da Silva e Orta of Brazil (1711–1793)
was the first woman in the Portuguese-speaking world to publish a
novel and the first Brazilian-born person to edit a book in Europe.
She advocated for the autonomy of the Indigenous and the rights of
women in science (Gargallo 2004: 80). Flora Tristán of
Perú (1803–1844) argued for women’s equality and
its important relationship to workers’ rights (Gargallo 2004:
80). Argentinian abolitionist Juana Manso (1819–1875) detailed
education and philosophical instruction as a route to the moral and
intellectual emancipation of women. This position was taken up at the
end of the century by figures like Rita Cetina Gutiérrez of
Mexico (1846–1908) and Visitación Padilla of Honduras
(1882–1960) (Gargallo 2009: 418). Cetina Gutiérrez
founded La Siempreviva in Mérida, Mexico’s first secular
school for poor girls and an art college for young women. She is cited
as one of Mexico’s first feminists who promoted secular
education of women and fought for their self-determination. Padilla
founded the Sociedad Cultural Feminina, which promoted access to
education, especially for women. Venezuelan Teresa de la Parra
(1889-1936) used writing as a mechanism of resistance from which to
question the limitations of the gendered experience exemplifying the
way that literature can be both political and philosophical. Broadly
speaking, feminist ideas are rooted in women’s personal
experience and this relationship is readily explored through
literature, poetry, and testimonial narrative that concretely reflects
the feminist maxim “the personal is political” (Schutte
1993: 213).  

The existence of early Latin American feminist ideas was not attended
to until years after their inception. The impact of ideas centering on
women’s rights to intellectual and educational life, equality,
and workers’ rights was not immediate since they were not given
importance in their respective contexts. During the feminist movements
of the 20th century, many of these figures re-emerged as
part of a Latin American feminist theoretical landscape (Gargallo
2004: 81). Early Latin American feminist ideas came to be evaluated
through historical memory that gives weight to the claim that Latin
American feminist ideas existed prior to the women’s movements
of the 1960s and 1970s. The existence of early Latin American
feminist ideas that predate the feminist movement questions the
relationship between women, history, and epistemology (Palacios
2007: 104). In this context, the philosophical demand is a
reading of the past complexly incorporating women as political actors
and knowledge producers even if they were not seen as such in their
times.
